marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Tax receipts, indentures, and land grants from the Butler family.
Robert Burns letter to William Dunbar,

Letter from Burns to William Dunbar (d. 1807) in Edinburgh thanking him for the gift of a set of the writings of Edmund Spenser. Burns closed the letter with a stanza of poetry. Transcription of the letter is included. Part of the Harry L. and Mary K. Dalton Collection.
Butler (1744-1822) was born in Ireland and served as a British army officer. He married and settled in Prince William's Parish (Beaufort County) South Carolina, and served two terms in Congress.
Papers discuss legal and financial matters. One is concerned with paying off a mortgage; one is a bill of exchange signed over to Butler in 1791.

Various family letters and statements of accounts, including an estate account (1802) that lists sales of land and slaves, as well as an order placed for household goods (7 November 1879). Topics of interest in the letters include tobacco trade and prices, Presbyterian camp meetings, and the health of family members. Also, there is a letter from Luke L. Burwell to his brother Lewis (11 September 1849), in which Luke counters charges of plantation mismanagement made by his overseer.

Letters and papers of Benjamin Burroughs and his overseer, John George, concerning the sale of horses, furniture, tools, livestock, and enslaved people as well as improvements at Cold Spring Plantation. Included also is a letter, 1847, from Theodore S. Fay in Berlin, commenting on his travels in Europe.
Collection contains business papers of David Burroughs concerning bonds for debt, apprenticeship papers, and a land deed from the town of Phelps, N.Y.
Superintendent of schools for Forsyth County, N.C.

Personal and business papers of Butner, consisting of personal letters, including one of 1855 describing a balloon ascension at Salem, N.C.; correspondence relating to education in North Carolina and school affairs in Forsyth County; rough minutes of the Forsyth County Board of Education, 1890-1895; and a temporary school register for Bethania Public School, 1904-1905. Correspondents include John Franklin Heitman and J.W. Giles.
Resident of Lowell and Littleton (Middlesex Co.), Mass.
Family correspondence of Augusta A. and Elethine Burnham, containing information of Lowell Institute, the textile mills, and rural life in New Hampshire.

Miscellaneous family papers, including letters, Henry Burrow's will, as well as various deeds and financial papers regarding Elizabeth Burrow's management of her husband Henry's estate. Henry Burrow served in the Civil War and died in a Richmond hospital around 1863 as a result of his injuries. Included are three letters he posted to his wife from the hospital and a fragment of the letter sent to Elizabeth informing her of his death. The collection also contains an advertising booklet published by Ford Motor Company (1912); undated obituaries for several Thomasville citizens; a copy of a Thomasville Chair Company newsletter, THE CHAIRMAKER (June 1924); and miscellaneous and financial papers for the Ragan family.

Three business papers from Burtz, including an 1866 agreement with freedman William Parks for land and supplies furnished to Parks as a tenant farmer in return for half of the crop. Includes details on mules, wagons, fencing, and the "patch" of the freedman.
Originally part of the Marmaduke Floyd Collection.
Resident of Lawrenceville and Stone Mountain (DeKalb Co.), Ga; sister to Clarinda and to brothers Dr. R.S. Butler, Altamount T. Butler, and Thomas C. Butler, soldiers in the Confederate Army.

Collection consists largely of letters to Louisa Butler from her brothers, Dr. R. S. Butler, Altamount T. Butler, and Thomas C. Butler; dates chiefly from the Civil War period. All brothers served in the Confederate Army. Thomas C. died in the hospital of Camp Winder in Richmond on May 7, 1862. Altamount R. and R. S. both survived the war, although it appears R. S. died in 1874 of complicates from wartime injuries or exposure. R. S. Butler was a physician from Palatka, Florida. Louisa, her sister Clarinda, and their mother lived in Lawrenceville, Ga., and moved to Atlanta following the Civil War.

The letters reveal conditions in army and civilian life during the Civil War, as well as document the family's poverty. The sisters and their mother depended on money sent by their brothers. R. S. Butler's letters also reflect conditions in the vicinity of Palatka, Florida, both before and after the war.
Maria Buttner lived in Bethania (Forsyth Co.), N.C.

Letter to her brother, Albert T.J. Buttner in Whiteville, N.C. Topics include agriculture, family news, a Jewish wedding, and an election of 1852. Buttner made particularly interesting comments comparing the repression of women and slaves: "I always take it for granted that people who have such 'glass cupboard['] reasons are great advocates for slavery, either of women or negroes; for it seems as though we were considered in the same light, by some great souled people ..." (02-165).
Naturalist and author, born in Roxbury, N.Y.

Collection consists of an autograph copy, signed in pencil, of notes for "The Friendly Rocks," as well as a letter, poem, photograph, and volume. Burroughs wrote the letter to Mary Hoyt Freligh (year unknown) concerning his friend, William Vanamee. The poem is titled "Waiting," and was printed in Knickerbocker's magazine in 1863. The photograph is a portrait of Burroughs. The volume is a Guardian and Administration book kept in Jefferson Co., Arkansas, which has accounts of six people for which Burroughs was apparently an administrator.
Collection consists of letters between Burrows and his brother, Frank Burrows.
Methodist minister, of Halifax County, N.C.

Letters to Rev. R.O. Burton relating to church affairs, business matters, the Civil War, and the education of his son, Andrew Joyner Burton (b. 1848), at Belmont, N.C., and at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. Included is an itemized account of Andrew's expenses at the University, 1863.
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Teacher prior to the Civil War; Union soldier in the 1st Regiment of Kentucky Infantry Volunteers during the war; from Wilmington (Clinton Co.), Ohio.

Personal letters of Busbey concerning politics in Ohio; letters express opinions on Copperheads, other Democrats, Republicans, and the unsuccessful gubernatorial race of Clement Vallandigham against Republican John Brough in 1863. Letters also mention the Freemasons; crime in Ohio; the life of a soldier; and CSA attacks on Union boats near Palmyra, Tennessee, and the burning of that town by the Union troops.
Soldier, 44th Indiana Infantry, and state legislator, from Salem Center, Steuben Co., Ind.

Civil War letters between Butler and his future wife, Harriet M. Fuller, concerning camp life; military activities, especially the battle of Stones River (a.k.a. Murfreesboro), Buell's pursuit of Bragg in 1862, and the Vicksburg campaign; his illness and subsequent discharge; and life on the home front.
Stones River, Battle of, Murfreesboro, Tenn., 1862-1863.
Collection consists of letters to Burton's cousin, James T. Bland, who was a prisoner of war in Elmira, N.Y.
Two brief and nearly illegible notes concerned with a knitting machine.
Massachusetts legislator, Federal general, U.S. congressman, and governor of Massachusetts.

Primarily letters, mostly in the 1880s to O.D. Barrett (Washington, D.C.) regarding financial matters. The collection also includes letters referencing organized labor and the eight-hour law (1886), and Butler's protective attitude toward former enslaved people (1864?).
Cataloged from Guide and Accession Records, 1936-1977.
Resident of Waterford, Saratoga Co., N.Y.

Collection consists of letters received by Button from Myron Adams, Jr. Although the two had not met, they were introduced by a mutual friend. Adams' letters contain scattered references to his work in the U.S. Signal Corps, as well as his reflections and discussions on religion, education, and his tentative plans to study law following his release from the Army.
Engineer, inventor, and farmer, of Leeds, England, and Middleburg, Va.

Letterpress book and letters dealing with business matters. Much of the early correspondence concerns Burton's efforts to secure remuneration from either the British or American governments, or from private manufacturers in both countries, for their use of his process of manufacturing steel gun barrels. Included are references to labor conditions in England and the business affairs of various English and American armament companies. The bulk of the material after 1873, when Burton emigrated to America, concerns the management of his farm, including orders for supplies, receipts, sales of stock and produce, and sales and purchases of land in Virginia, West Virginia, and Georgia.
William Henry Burr was an atheist and newspaper reporter; one of his popular works was "Self-Contradictions of the Bible."

Collection comprises two letters by William Henry Burr. Topics in the 1883 letter include a scam involving "that fellow 'Kellogg'" and rumored presidential scandals involving Chester Arthur and James Garfield. The 1897 letter involves Burr's making a copy of a letter by Thomas Paine regarding Paine's service as an editor for the Pennsylvania Magazine.
Letter from Butler to Sadler (possibly Sir Michael Ernest Sadler) from Cassel, Germany, where Butler recounted his conversations with Kaiser Wilhelm II.
Newspaper editor and political leader of Democratic Party in Virginia.

Collection consists of three letters; two are concerned with a speech Byrd was to make to the Lions Club Convention on the proposed amendments to the Virginia Constitution. The third item is an invitation to a farewell dinner given for Commander Richard Evelyn Byrd by the Byrd Aviation Associates for the Byrd Antartic Expedition in New York on July 25, 1928.
